Program  The  proposed  Development  Policy  Support  Program  (DPSP)  is 
Description  embedded  in  the  Government’s  Medium  Term  Development  Plan 
(RPJM) for 2004-2009. It supports the RPJM’s broad goal of stimulating 
higher and sustainable economic growth (to 7% average annual growth 
by 2009 up from levels around 4% prior to 2004) and halving poverty (to 
8.2% by 2009 from 16.6% in 2004). To achieve these goals, the DPSP 
is a policy engagement tool that accelerates economy-wide and cross 
cutting reforms.  More specifically, it has involved the implementation of 
a set of policy actions in four core areas to (i) improve macroeconomic 
stability and creditworthiness; (ii) promote investments; (iii) strengthen 
the financial sector; and (iv) enhance the quality of public financial 
management and reduce corruption. Supported by a $200 million single 
tranche  operation,  the  DPSP’s  key  achievements  are  the  upfront 
implementation of the core policy actions, and the development and 
building of full Government commitment for a forward-looking program 
that deepens the reforms in the core areas, while striving to strengthen 
public service delivery to the poor.  
   
Rationale  Exiting the International Monetary Fund-supported program, to ensure 
policy continuity and to deepen the post-crisis reforms, in a period of 
political transition leading up to the Presidential elections, in September 
2003 the Government announced a structural reform package - the 
White  Paper.  Recognizing  the  centrality  of  this  Paper,  the  principal 
development partners, including ADB, supported its formulation as well 
as implementation. ADB specifically focused on deepening reforms in 
finance  and  governance,  building  on  post-crisis  sector  restructuring 
outcomes.  Substantial  ADB  technical  assistance  and  economic  and 
sector  work  supported  White  Paper  implementation.  In  parallel,  the 
World Bank supported White Paper implementation over the period 
2003–2004 with a Development Policy Loan (DPL) (cofinanced by the 
Government of Japan).  The DPL framework has its origin in the World 
Bank’s Country Assistance Strategy, which advocates support for the 
Government’s macroeconomic and crosscutting reforms through three 
sequentially designed DPLs.  
 
Building on the White Paper and developing its own priorities, the new 
Government, which assumed office in October 2004, announced the 
RPJM  for  2004–2009  in  November  2005.  The  RPJM  has  three 
objectives: peace and security, justice and democracy, and prosperity

ii 
for all. The Government has further instituted a system of annual work 
plans (RKP), approved each year by the Cabinet to help implement 
RPJM. 
 
To provide effective impetus to the RPJM, the Government requested 
the  principal  development  partners,  at  the  Consultative  Group  on 
Indonesia  meeting  in  January  2005,  to  enhance  and  intensify  their 
macroeconomic and sector policy engagement structured around the 
RPJM.  In  response,  a  common  policy  agenda  was  developed  and 
agreed upon during formulation of the DPSP. The DPSP serves as a 
tool to anchor and track progress in four principal areas: promoting 
macroeconomic  stability,  improving  the  investment  climate, 
strengthening the financial sector, and strengthening public financial 
management and anticorruption. As an integral part of the DPSP, the 
Government has shown strong commitment for forward-looking reforms 
to guide RPJM implementation during 2006–2009. 
 
The DPSP aims to harmonize policy reform support of key development 
partners by providing parallel financing with the World Bank and the 
Government of Japan, which are processing a second phase of the 
Development Policy Loan (DPL-2). The DPSP effectively builds on and 
deepens sector-specific reforms supported by ADB through past and 
ongoing operations. 
 
The DPSP adheres to ADB’s recent efforts to reduce transaction costs 
for its developing member countries. The approach is also consistent 
with  ADB’s  reform  agenda,  as  outlined  in  the  Long-Term  Strategic 
Framework, Medium-Term Strategy, and the Middle-Income Country 
Initiative. The DPSP helps implement and fulfill ADB’s obligations to the 
Rome  Declaration  on  harmonizing  procedures  of  multilateral 
development banks (February 2003) and the recent Paris Declaration 
on Aid Effectiveness (March 2005).   
   
Impact and  The DPSP aims to (i) achieve and sustain higher economic growth 
Outcome  through  improved  fiscal  management  and  investment  climate,  and 
enhancing  financial  sector  soundness;  and  (ii)  reduce  poverty  and 
unemployment by reorienting public expenditures to productive needs, 
and by strengthening governance in public financial management. 
   
Financing Plan  The Government’s external financing needs for the 2005 budget are 
estimated at $3.6 billion, comprising $1.25 billion in program loans – to 
support the reforms – and $2.35 billion in project disbursements. In 
addition to the DPSP support of $200 million, the Government has 
requested $400 million from the World Bank through DPL-2 and parallel 
financing support (amount to be determined) from the Government of 
Japan.

iii 
Loan Amount and  A  single-tranche  program  loan  of  $200  million  from  ADB’s  ordinary 
Terms  capital  resources  will  be  provided  under  ADB’s  London  interbank 
offered rate (LIBOR)-based lending facility. The loan will have a 15-year 
term, including a grace period of 3 years; an interest rate determined in 
accordance with ADB’s LIBOR-based lending facility; a commitment 
charge of 0.75% per annum; conversion options that may be exercised 
in accordance with the draft loan agreement, the loan regulations, and 
ADB’s conversion guidelines; and such other terms and conditions set 
forth in the draft program loan agreement. 
   
Disbursement  The loan will be disbursed in a single tranche upon declaration of loan 
effectiveness. 
   
Program Period and  The DPSP period is from 1 January 2005 to 30 June 2006. All actions 
Tranching  included in the Policy Matrix have been implemented during the course 
of 2005. The DPSP fits within the overall reform agenda supported 
under the DPLs, which covers 2003–2007. 
   
Executing Agency  Ministry of Finance 
   
Procurement  The loan proceeds will be used to finance the full foreign exchange 
costs (excluding local duties and taxes) of items produced and procured 
in  ADB  member  countries,  excluding  ineligible  items  and  imports 
financed by other bilateral and multilateral sources. In accordance with 
the provisions of ADB’s Simplification of Disbursement Procedures and 
Related Requirements for Program Loans, the loan proceeds will be 
disbursed to the Republic of Indonesia as the Borrower. No supporting 
import documentation will be required, if, during each year when loan 
proceeds are expected to be disbursed, the value of Indonesia’s total 
imports minus imports from nonmember countries, ineligible imports, 
and imports financed under other official development assistance is 
equal  to  or  greater  than  the  amount  of  the  loan  expected  to  be 
disbursed during such year. The Government will certify its compliance 
with  this  formula  with  each  withdrawal  request.  Otherwise,  import 
documentation  under  existing  procedures  will  be  required.  ADB 
reserves the right to audit the use of loan proceeds and verify the 
accuracy of the Government’s certification.

macroeconomic stability and creditworthiness; improved investment 
climate, reduced corruption, and improved governance; 
 
(ii) consolidation of recent macroeconomic and policy reforms leading 
to  the  formulation  of  a  credible  medium-term  public  expenditure 
framework, backed by measures to curtail wasteful public spending; 
 
(iii) institutional  development  within  Government  institutions,  Bank 
Indonesia, and banks;

(iv) greater public confidence in the banking system stemming from the 
introduction of the deposit protection scheme; 
 
(v) sustained ADB engagement in policy dialogue with the Government 
on the direction and content of, and strategies for, its economic, 
structural, and institutional reform agenda - with the DPSP providing 
for  policy  continuity  and  consistency  in  sectors  where  ADB  has

(vi) facilitation, through cross-cutting reforms, of sector-specific reforms

(vii) harmonization  and  parallel  financing  by  the  key  development

Risks and Mitigating  The DPSP is subject to the following risks: 
Measures   
(i)  Economic  volatility  may  increase  if  the  Government  does  not 
sustain the reform momentum to follow up on the recent reduction in 
fuel subsidies (including maintaining appropriate interest rates and 
investment climate reforms). This risk is mitigated by the clear policy 
stance  taken  thus  far  by  the  Government  and  Bank  Indonesia. 
Following the recent currency market volatility, the need for rapid 
policy  adjustment  on  the  domestic  front  in  line  with  key  global 
developments is now clearly recognized. 
 
(ii) Rising interest rates may trigger financial stress in debt markets with 
contagion effects on banks and mutual funds. In turn, this may 
affect growth prospects.  
 
(iii) Increased social tensions could result from the reduction of fuel 
subsidies announced on 1 October 2005. Thus far no major protests 
have been experienced; the success of the ongoing unconditional 
cash transfers program is vital in containing public disenchantment. 
This  risk  is  mitigated  by  the  Government’s  focus  on  ongoing 
evaluation of this program, with ADB support. The Government also 
aims to formulate a broad-based public expenditure reorientation 
program; an area where ADB is actively involved. 
 
(iv) The external environment may deteriorate, if high oil-prices continue 
resulting in a slowdown in world economic growth and trade, and 
unfavorable  conditions  in  world  financial  markets.  The 
Government’s October 2005 policy package provides for attracting 
investments  in  the  oil  and  gas  sector,  which  in  turn  will  help 
Indonesia effectively manage its natural resources and reap the 
benefits of any windfall gains.  
 
(v)  Heightened security alerts stemming from sectarian and regional 
conflicts, and terrorism could slow foreign direct investment and set 
back the recovering tourism industry.

I.  THE PROPOSAL 
 
1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed loan 
to the Republic of Indonesia for the Development Policy Support Program (DPSP). The DPSP 
supports  the  common  development  policy  agenda  as  prepared  by  a  joint  team  of  the 
Government of Indonesia (the Government), Asian Development Bank (ADB), World Bank, and 
Government of Japan. The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1. 
 
II.  THE PROGRAM AND MACROECONOMIC CONTEXT 
 
A.  Development Strategies and Plan 
 
2.  In  September  2003,  the  Government  prepared  a  White  Paper,  setting  forth  broad-
ranging  macroeconomic  and  sector  reforms,  to  provide  policy  continuity  and  bridge  any 
credibility gap to emerge after Indonesia’s exit from the International Monetary Fund (IMF)-
supported program, as well as during the political transition leading to elections in 2004. The 
new  Government,  which  assumed  office  in  October  2004,  announced  the  Medium-Term 
Development Plan (RPJM) for 2004–2009 in November 2005. The RPJM has three objectives: 
peace and security, justice and democracy, and prosperity for all. The Government’s annual 
work plan (RKP), approved each year by the Cabinet, guides RPJM implementation. The RKP 
for  2006  has  seven  priority  areas  to:  reduce  poverty  and  disparity,  increase  employment, 
revitalize  agriculture,  improve  access  to  and  quality  of  education,  reduce  corruption, 
strengthening defense capacities, and rehabilitate and reconstruct Aceh and Nias (Figure 1).

3.  In  its  first  year,  the  new  Government  continued  the  fiscal  consolidation  process; 
launched  substantive  legal  and  regulatory  reforms  for  strengthening  decentralization, 
investment, and the infrastructure sectors; and reinvigorated the campaign against corruption, 
including pursuit of several high-profile cases. Efforts to address constraints in decentralization 
and the public expenditure program are aimed to reduce poverty and accelerate attainment of 
the Millennium Development Goals (MDGs). Notably, the Government has maintained a strong 
focus  on  its  medium-term  development  priorities,  despite  the  massive  devastation  and 
disruption caused by the December 2004 earthquake and tsunami. 
 
4.  To provide effective impetus to the RPJM, the Government requested the principal 
development partners, at the Consultative Group on Indonesia meeting in January 2005, to 
enhance and intensify their macroeconomic and sector policy engagement structured around 
the RPJM. In response, a common policy agenda was developed and agreed upon during the 
formulation of the DPSP. The DPSP serves as a tool to anchor and track progress in three 
principal  areas:  promoting  macroeconomic  stability,  improving  the  investment  climate,  and 
strengthening public financial management and anticorruption.  
 
B.  The DPSP – the Government and Development Partnership 
 
5.  Given  the  close  alignment  between  its  own  reform  agenda  and  the  DPSP,  the 
Government has shown its absolute ownership and commitment and engaged in policy dialogue 
in a seamless manner throughout DPSP formulation and implementation. The Government’s 
ownership of the DPSP policy agenda is underscored by its development policy letter addressed 
jointly to the Presidents of ADB and the World Bank (Appendix 2). 
 
6.  The DPSP and the Development Policy Loans. The World Bank’s Country Assistance 
Strategy (CAS) lays out the rationale and justification for a series of Development Policy Loans 
(DPL), subject to progress in (i) improving macroeconomic stability and creditworthiness; (ii) 
improving the investment climate; (iii) accelerating governance and anticorruption reforms; and 
(iv)  improving  service  delivery  to  the  poor.  Sequentially,  the  process,  led  fully  by  the 
Government, has three phases:  
 
(i)  DPL-1, financed by the World Bank ($300 million approved in December 2004) 
with parallel financing from the Government of Japan ($100 million approved in 
early 2005), supported the Government’s White Paper reforms and President 
Yudhoyono’s “100-Day Plan”. In parallel, ADB supported the formulation and 
implementation of the White Paper through reforms in finance and governance, 
building on post-crisis sector restructuring outcomes.1   
 
(ii)  DPL-2/DPSP, a product of joint missions and financing of the World Bank ($400 
million),  ADB  ($200  million),  and  the  Government  of  Japan  (support  being 
determined), was activated upon satisfactory compliance with the DPL-2 and 
CAS  triggers  (Appendixes  2  and  3).  The  DPL-2  focuses  on  the  first  three 
principal focus areas of the CAS: macroeconomic stability and creditworthiness,

7.  The DPSP and ADB’s Strategy. The DPSP is a key pillar of ADB’s emerging country 
strategy and program for 2006–2010. Under this, a dual-track approach is proposed to ensure 
continuity and sustainability of past ADB-supported initiatives. This would involve structuring 
ADB support through (i) participation in the DPLs to strengthen the macroeconomic and fiscal 
framework and address cross-cutting concerns; and (ii) sector-specific policy interventions. For 
example, in 2005, ADB launched upfront partnerships with the World Bank and the Government 
of Japan to develop a conceptual framework and design for infrastructure sector reform. All key 
development partners have a policy engagement in areas covered in the ADB-supported Local 
Government Finance and Governance Reform Sector Development Program,3 which provides 
an overall umbrella for decentralization policy reforms. Joint technical work is underway by both 
the ADB and the World Bank on poverty reduction and acceleration of MDGs.  
 
8.  The proposed ADB parallel financing support for the DPL (through the DPSP) and ADB-
supported and coordinated sector-specific interventions are among the key holistic attempts to 
align  and  harmonize  development  partner  strategies  with  Indonesia’s  country  strategy  and 
priorities. ADB’s participation in the DPL process and the parallel policy dialogue on sector 
reforms has been appreciated by Government. Over the medium-term, the dual-track approach 
will  help  reinforce  reforms  under  both  streams  and  facilitate  close  coordination  among 
development partners.  
 
9.  Linkage of DPSP, DPLs and RPJM. The DPSP, building on DPL-1, is anchored on 
DPL-2 and DPL-3 with enhancement to capture ADB’s continued policy engagement in the 
financial sector. The policy dialogue and fact-finding missions for the DPSP were an ongoing 
process that culminated in a policy matrix, which was firmed up during the joint Appraisal 
Mission in November 2005.4 The DPSP covers policy actions implemented during 2005, with the 
anticipation of continuous engagement over 2006–2007 to support the next phase. Figure 2 
presents the DPSP framework, and its linkage with the RPJM and the DPLs.

10.  Harmonization  and  Complementarity.  The  policy  components  and  actions  of  the 
DPSP are sequenced and paced to accommodate the prevailing political economy of Indonesia, 
where the legislature must fully buy into the agenda, where it takes time to ensure stakeholder 
ownership and effective implementation. Harmonization of strategies of development partners 
around the Government’s own program has bolstered further country ownership of the reforms 
and has helped forge a new relationship between the Government and its principal development 
partners. Further, harmonization around the reform programs, such as the DPLs and ADB-
supported sector reform initiatives, builds on the natural synergy and complementarities that 
exist among the development partners. Combining the strengths and expertise of each of the 
development partners has helped ensure quality and consistency of advice and reduce the 
transaction cost of policy dialogue. 
 
C.   Recent Economic Performance 
 
11.  Indonesia’s track record of economic management in recent years has been consistent 
and positive. During 2001–2004, real gross domestic product (GDP) grew steadily and fiscal 
consolidation was impressive, with the budget deficit declining from minus 3.2% of GDP to 
minus 1.1%, a reduction of about 2.1%. Effective monetary management stabilized inflation, 
interest rates, and the exchange rate (around Rp9,500); and foreign exchange reserves rose to 
about  $35  billion.  The  real  GDP  in  the  first  half  of  2005  grew  by  5.9%  driven  by  strong 
investment growth,5 reversing the earlier consumption-led growth pattern, as reflected in the rise 
in import of capital goods and accelerating growth in the nontradable sectors. Despite strong 
export growth, the rise in imports due to adverse developments in the oil and gas sector led to a 
rise in the external current account deficit. The combination of these events resulted in a 
cumulative drawdown of foreign exchange reserves by nearly $6 billion in the past few months, 
to $32 billion in September 2005.  
 
12.  A few disturbing trends underlie this favorable economic picture. Until recently, growth 
has been primarily consumption led, with investment levels declining. Fiscal compression at the 
national  level,  coupled  with  the  challenges  of  decentralization,  precipitated  by  weak 
intergovernment fiscal relations and lack of effective onlending arrangements for assistance to 
local governments, have affected the quantity and quality of public service delivery. 
  
13.  Economic outcomes in 2005 have been further impacted by the (i) preoccupation in the 
first quarter of 2005 with rescue, recovery, and rehabilitation efforts in Aceh,6 which delayed 
economywide reforms; and (ii) sharp rise in international oil prices and higher than projected 
fuel imports.7 The latter increased the fuel oil subsidy bill from Rp34 trillion (based on $24 per 
barrel oil price) to around Rp110 trillion (based on $54 per barrel). Uncertainty about the 
timetable for the gradual removal of fuel subsidies created short-term economic volatility in 
financial markets. Global interest rate pressures and slow adjustments of domestic interest rates 
generated instability in exchange markets causing the rupiah to depreciate to Rp11,400 to the 
dollar  in  early  September  2005.  Subsequent  adjustments  in  interest  rates  and  the  sharp 
reduction in fuel subsidies have helped stabilize the exchange rate, though inflation spiraled in 
October (para.36).8

D.  Issues and Opportunities 
 
15.  While the Government has embarked on a program of bold reforms, the reforms are far 
from  being  complete.  The  unfinished  reform  agenda  has  provided  the  opportunity  for  the 
development partners to lend support through a series of forward-looking interventions targeting 
specific areas. 
 
16.  Macroeconomic and Fiscal Policies. Stringent fiscal policy has helped reduce the 
budget deficit but has squeezed development spending, which sharply declined after the onset 
of the crisis and stagnated at 2–3% of GDP during 1998–2005, as compared with 7–8% prior to 
1997. Over the same period, recurrent expenditures declined from about 12% of GDP to about 
9%.  In  2004,  public  expenditures  came  under  renewed  pressures  as  the  fuel  subsidies 
increased to 3.5% of GDP, leaving less than Rp80 trillion for development expenditures. Despite 
being an oil-producing country, Indonesia has not been able to reap any significant gains from 
the favorable global oil market environment due to lack of investments in oil exploration and 
development. 
  
17.  In proportional terms, the approved 2005 budget allocations present a similar picture to 
that of 2004, with revised fuel subsidies estimated at about Rp89.5 trillion, leaving limited 
resources for development needs. Nonetheless, the recent reduction in fuel subsidies has 
provided the Government with significant scope to reorient public expenditures to achieve the 
Government’s dual goal of accelerated economic growth and poverty reduction. 
 
18.  Tax Framework. Businesses are required to file seven different types of tax returns 
every month. Based on a recent survey undertaken by the World Bank, firms devote on average 
45 person-days each month for this purpose. Indonesia must move to a more streamlined tax-
filing system. Delayed tax refunds impose a major burden on firms, particularly small and 
medium-sized  enterprises  (SMEs),  since  advance  tax  payments  tie  up  a  large  amount  of 
working capital. Value-added tax (VAT) refunds alone take an average of 5 months.

19.  Debt Management. The Government has managed to gradually decrease the level of 
debt over the last few years, from 91% of GDP in 2000 to 52% by mid-2005. The overall debt is 
projected to decline to about 30% of GDP by 2010. Debt sustainability analysis, undertaken by 
the World Bank and IMF, indicate that both external and domestic public debt is fairly robust to 
shocks in exchange rates, interest rates, and GDP trends. However, considering that slightly 
more than half of the outstanding debt, or about $66 billion, is denominated in foreign currency, 
long-term, and owed to noncommercial lenders, one of the main risks facing Indonesia is 
exchange rate risk. Recent trends in interest rates and the move to issue sovereign bonds are 
to eventually magnify interest rate risks. The Government needs to adopt a clear strategy to 
manage such risk as it pursues its strategy to gradually reduce overall debt. 
 
20.  Investment Constraints. After years of declining investments, signs of recovery are 
evident, although continued low investments remain a concern. The weak legal and regulatory 
framework  for  investment,  problems  of  interpretation  and  application  of  the  law  and 
enforceability  of  contractual  obligations  have  led  to  high-profile  and  high-value  investment 
disputes, some of them concluded in favor of vested interests and involving bankruptcy litigation 
against well-known companies with foreign shareholding. The approval process for foreign 
investments by the Investment Coordinating Board is protracted. Indonesia lags other Asian 
countries in this area: it takes 80–151 days on average to register and establish a locally owned 
limited liability company in Indonesia, compared to 56 days in Viet Nam, 41 days in the People's 
Republic  of  China,  and  30  days  in  Malaysia.  Nontransparent  processes  leave  scope  for 
discretion in verification and approval of investment applications, and corruption.10
 
21.  Infrastructure Development. While infrastructure investments in Indonesia exceeded 
5% of GDP prior to the financial crisis, they have subsequently fallen and not recovered beyond 
2-3% of GDP. Public service provision and coverage are low across all sectors, but particularly 
low in telecommunications, roads, power, and water supply and sanitation, and in areas outside 
Java, resulting in widening economic and social disparities. The Government estimates the 
infrastructure investment requirements at around $145 billion for 2005–2009. It further estimates 
that only 17% can be financed from the national budget, and 7% by official development 
assistance, which will be largely used for promoting public-private partnerships. This means that 
the bulk of the requirements will have to be met by private capital. The infrastructure financing 
constraints are aggravated by the lack of depth and diversification in the financial system, which 
does not provide long-term capital.  
 
22.  Investors  are  concerned  about  the  policy,  legal,  and  regulatory  distortions  in  the 
infrastructure  sectors,  and  face  country  risks  as  recourse  to  the  judicial  system  is  weak. 
Although a number of projects that halted after the crisis have been renegotiated, gaps in sector 
policies and recent adverse outcomes, such as the annulment of the Electricity Law by the 
Constitutional Court in December 2004 have negatively affected investor confidence. Lack of 
strong coordination across sector ministries also adversely affects infrastructure investment. 
The National Committee for the Acceleration of Infrastructure Development (KKPPI) has been 
established  and  strengthened  through  a  Presidential  Decree  in  2005,  but  it  needs  strong 
technical and administrative support to function as an effective coordination mechanism. Due to 
the  legal  and  country risks,  the Government  needs  to adopt  a  risk-sharing  mechanism  to 
mitigate against the legal and regulatory uncertainties faced by investors. Transaction quality 
needs to be ensured by thorough project preparation and transparent bidding process. There is 
a need for an effective mechanism for an independent and impartial review, roles that can be 
played only by a strong KKPPI.

23.  Financial Sector. Indonesia’s financial sector has stabilized but continues to exhibit 
structural  vulnerabilities  and  risks.  The  financial  performance  of  Indonesia’s  banks  is 
comparable or better than other developing countries in the region and gross nonperforming 
loan ratios have declined over time from above 12% in 2001 to 7% by mid-2005, although some 
large state-owned commercial banks continue to carry large nonperforming loans. Financial 
intermediation is increasing, although its growth is impacted by upward pressure on interest rate 
and credit and operational risks in the system. Banks have as yet not fully adopted sound risk 
management systems. Recent scandals in some banks—including large state-owned banks as 
well as smaller, reasonably well-managed private banks—manifest weak corporate and financial 
governance practices. Lack of an effective financial safety net and liquidity support for the 
banking system pose a systemic risk to the system.11 Nonbank financial institutions (NBFIs) still 
account for a relatively low 16% of total financial assets. While the Indonesian capital market 
has been the best performing in the region and equity market capitalization registered triple-fold 
growth in recent years, issues of breadth and depth of the market and enforcement of regulation 
and supervision remain a concern. The long-term debt market has been constrained by delays 
in pension and insurance sector reforms. The financial sector lacks innovation, both at the 
institution and product level. Much of the liquidity is locked up in Government bonds.  
  
24.  Financial  Management  and  Anticorruption.  The  key  concerns  in  public  financial 
management  are  (i)  an  outdated  legal  environment;  (ii)  an  opaque  and  inefficient  budget 
formulation process, and the separation of recurrent and development budgets; (iii) an inefficient 
payments  system  and  weak  monitoring  arrangements;  (iv)  fragmented  cash  management 
arrangements; (v) unreliable accounting, auditing, and reporting systems; and (vii) overlaps 
between external and internal audit agencies, reflecting unclear roles and responsibilities. Public 
and investor perception surveys (such as those by Transparency International) indicate that 
corruption is evident at all levels in the public sector. Legal and regulatory uncertainty in most 
sectors  acts  as  a  major  impediment  to  good  governance.  Public  procurement  remains  a 
challenging  area  of  reform;  malpractices  here  have  impeded  development  spending.  The 
President  has  made  corruption  eradication  a  top  priority,  and  the  establishment  of  the 
Corruption  Eradication  Commission  (KPK)  has  brought  new  hope.  Persistence  in  the 
Government’s anticorruption efforts and sound enforcement will be vital to reducing corruption in 
public life.  
 
E.  Lessons Learned  
25.  The role of adjustment lending as a vehicle for economic growth and poverty reduction 
has come under scrutiny by a number of task forces and studies.12 This body of analytical 
literature agrees that adjustment lending, originally conceived as a financing vehicle for short-
term balance of payments or budget support, has also evolved into an important development 
instrument for supporting economic, social, and sector reforms, especially in middle-income 
countries.  
 
26.  Early adjustment lending had a mixed performance record. The concerns stem largely 
from  the  evidence  that  past  reform  programs  were  structured  around  unrealistic  and  rigid

assessment of ownership and institutional capacities. At the same time, conditions tended to be 
numerous and not well prioritized. Rigid reform conditionalities by themselves cannot lead to the 
adoption of effective policies in absence of consensus and ownership of reform. Rather than 
being prescriptive, conditionalities should be based on good diagnostic and analytical work and 
geared to evolving country circumstances and structured around open and informed debate 
about policy reform. 
 
27.  Many multiyear and multitranche operations have had implementation difficulties, in part 
because ambitious, multiyear reform agendas were in excess of the institutional capacity and 
political economy of the country. For example, the adjustment lending experience of the World 
Bank indicates that during 1990-1999, 39% of two-tranche operations and 63% of three-tranche 
operations had waivers or cancellations.13 ADB experience has been similar. As a result, as an 
alternative,  the  World  Bank  has  now  moved  increasingly  to  a  series  of  single-tranche 
operations, with a well-defined, medium-term (programmatic) framework specified at the outset, 
including completed up-front reform actions and triggers for subsequent operations. The DPLs 
fit into this mold.  
 
28.  For effective development results, the policy agenda needs to be backed by broader 
public sector reforms that aim to address thematic and cross-cutting issues of governance, 
public financial management, procurement, and accountability. At the same time, given the lack 
of responsiveness of the private sector to mere adoption of policies and passage of laws, the 
development  debate  advocates  emphasis  on  institutional  development,  capacity  building, 
implementation of laws and policies, and improvements in procedures and systems. 
 
29.  In light of this evidence, evaluation studies increasingly advocate that the following steps 
are imperative when designing adjustment lending: 
 
(i)  Assess carefully the environment in which the reform agenda is planned, as well 
as the degree of country commitment, ownership, and readiness shown by the 
Government. 
(ii)  Ensure  that  the  development  agenda  encompasses  longer  term  economic, 
social, and institutional issues; and includes the flexibility to cope with emerging 
changes and institutional problems. 
(iii)  Promote broader stakeholder participation to obtain adequate buy-in and mitigate 
vested interests. 
(iv)  Ensure that macroeconomic and fiscal stability measures adequately reinforce, 
and  are  supported  by,  a  proper  environment  for  investment,  financial 
management, and governance.  
(v)  Use  adjustment  lending  as  a  flexible  development  instrument  to  nurture  an 
effective  development  partnership  that  evolves  in  tandem  with  the  country’s 
broader  development  agendas  and  to  build  consensus  among  development 
partners on policy advice.

33.  The DPSP recognizes Indonesia’s positive track record of macroeconomic management, 
overall stability and fiscal consolidation after the 1997 financial crisis, leading to its exit from the 
IMF-supported program in 2003. However, some fundamental changes in Government strategy 
and  policy  to  enhance  the  quality  of  fiscal  management  are  needed.  Areas  of  critical 
significance  targeted  under  the  DPSP  include  (i)  reducing  distortionary  fuel  subsidies,  (ii) 
reorienting public spending to support poverty reduction programs, (iii) introducing tax reforms, 
(iv)  improving  debt  management,  and  (v)  streamlining  intergovernmental  borrowing.  A 
description of specific policy measures and actions under these areas follows. 
 
34.  Reduction in Subsidies to the Non-Poor. The fuel subsidy program has entailed high 
fiscal and economic costs, which compounded in 2005 with oil prices spiraling to unprecedented 
levels. Fuel prices for most products have been below international levels, with gasoline and 
kerosene at about 45% and 12% of international prices, respectively. As fuel subsidies were 
regressive, largely benefiting the middle-class and curtailing resources for productive uses, 
including poverty reduction, the DPSP supports their reduction from the original budgeted level

of about $13 billion to $9 billion for 2005. Following three rounds of fuel price increases in 2005, 
the Government has cumulatively raised fuel prices by 165%, an unprecedented magnitude 
since a 12% increase in 2000, followed by a 30% increase in 2001.16  
 
35.  In 2005, the Government adopted the following measures to reduce subsidies to the 
non-poor: 
 
(i)  all oil products: prices increased on average by 29% in March 2005; 
(ii)  mining-based industries: prices were brought closer to international parity in July 
2005; 
(iii)  all industrial users with an average monthly fuel consumption of 500,000 liters or 
more: prices were brought closer to international parity in August 2005; and 
(iv)  gasoline,  automotive  diesel,  and  kerosene  for  individual  consumption:  prices 
increased on average by 126.6% in October 2005. 
 
36.  Impact of Subsidy Reduction. The reduction in fuel subsidies will have clear medium- 
to long-term benefits. In the immediate short term, however, it will affect growth through higher 
inflation and interest rates. While the first round of subsidy reduction in March 2005 did not lead 
to a significant overall increase in inflation, the October increase in fuel prices has led to a sharp 
increase in inflation of 18% year-on-year. In the short term, growth may be affected by Bank 
Indonesia’s move to raise interest rates by 225 basis points to 12.25% in November, a measure 
that will slow credit growth. Nonetheless, the reduction in fuel subsidy has helped contain the 
planned fiscal deficit for 2005 at Rp48.3 trillion, or minus 0.9% of GDP, close to the target, while 
providing a window for improving the quality of fiscal management. Incorporating the impact of 
subsidy reduction and tax reforms, the fiscal deficit for 2006 is forecast to be 0.7% of GDP.  
 
37.  Reorienting  Public  Expenditures.  Fiscal  consolidation  pressures,  coupled  with 
mounting fuel subsidies, have squeezed public expenditure growth. Recognizing the adverse 
consequences of reduced public spending, under the DPSP the Government has reoriented the 
fuel subsidy savings to priority social sector and poverty reduction programs. Consistent with 
these goals, the Government has raised the resource allocations in various areas of the 2006 
budget over 2005 budget allocations: 
 
(i)  development and social spending increased from 3.2% to 3.7% of GDP; 
(ii)  transfers to the regions through block grants increased from 3.3% to 4.8% of 
GDP (or Rp153.8 trillion); and 
(iii)  doubling of regional special purpose grants from Rp4.8 trillion to Rp11.6 trillion.  
 
38.  Besides allowing for growth in public expenditures in the social sectors, in March 2005 
the Government began financing the Compensation Program for Reduction in Fuel Subsidies 
(PKPS) to partly mitigate the social and political consequences of the sharp rise in fuel prices, 
and to create jobs and boost growth. The PKPS includes the following: 
 
(i)  Unconditional  cash  transfers  were  made  to  15.5  million  poor  households, 
amounting to $10 per household/month (payments made quarterly, with the first

which  budget  spending  in  2005  is  close  to  Rp5  trillion.  The  transfers  are 
channeled  to  households  with  authorized  identification  cards  through  local 
branches of the post office and Bank Rakyat Indonesia.

and businesses organized on Shariah (Islamic) principles.  
 
(iv)  The VAT will be extended to new areas (such as mining), while exempting others 
(such as securitization, leasing, electricity and water, and Shariah banking).  
 
(v)  Taxes will be increased on luxury goods and services up to 200% from the 
current 75%. 
 
(vi)  Procedural changes in the Tax Administration Law will (a) reduce the statutory 
limit  for  tax  assessment  from  10  years  to  5  years,  (b)  allow  for  automatic 
extension of filing deadlines for corporate income tax, (c) exempt publicly listed 
companies from separate tax audits as their taxes are required to be audited by 
public  accountants,  (d)  waive  the  requirement  that  every  refund  request  be 
audited,  and  (e)  allow  for  greater  oversight  of  the  Tax  Department  by  the 
inspector general of the Ministry of Finance (MOF). 
 
41.  Impact of Tax Reforms. The tax reform measures are not revenue neutral; independent 
estimates suggest they could result in a tax revenue loss of up to 0.5% of GDP. However, the 
Government expects to offset this potential loss in revenue through better compliance and 
tightening of tax administration. Tax receipts to date in 2005 are considerably above 2004 
levels; non-oil taxes to the end of August 2005 increased by 26%. Revenue gains are likely to 
emerge more fully next year with full expansion in the tax base and better registration. Owing to 
measures adopted by the Government, the number of taxpayers has steadily increased, from 
1.98 million in 2000 to 3.67 million at the end of 2004, and to 10 million as of October 2005. 
 
42.  The  public  perception  of  the  tax  system  is  improving.  An  independent  survey  in 
September 2005 by the Large Taxpayers Office found that 81% of taxpayers were satisfied with 
overall services; 84% found tax filing easier, and 78% reported they have seen positive changes 
in tax officer behavior.19 The revisions to the Tax Administration Law, however, have been 
controversial. The business community has expressed serious concerns on increased powers 
being given to tax authorities, including the possible use of criminal sanctions against taxpayers.

46.  Impact of Improved Debt Management. The Government’s debt management strategy 
is yielding results. Overall public debt has fallen from 91% of GDP in 2000 to 59% in 2003, and 
to 52% by June 2005. During 2000–2005, the outstanding domestic debt declined from 47% of 
GDP to 25%, and external debt from 44% to 27%. Public sector debt has been reprofiled, 
effectively resulting in the amount of commercial debt being managed comprising 2–3% of 
overall external debt. Maturities have been lengthened with average time to maturity increasing 
from  5.9  years  in  2000  to  7.4  years  in  June  2005.  Sound  fiscal  and  macroeconomic

debt markets. However, while debt-service costs have declined to 6% of GDP, they still account

debt to 30% of GDP by 2010, although debt-threshold assessments indicate a debt level in the 
range of 35–42% of GDP would be appropriate (Appendix 6). The Government's approach to 
gradual debt reduction will release additional resources for public expenditure and poverty 
reduction programs. In quantitative terms, the Government's current strategy would reduce the 
debt stock by about $11 billion–$16 billion annually through 2006–2010, which could provide a 
significant expenditure cushion.

51.  Infrastructure Reforms. The reform measures introduced under the DPSP in this area 
include the following: 
 
(i)  Enhance institutional coordination to promote private sector participation (PSP) 
and  public-private  partnerships  (PPP)  in  infrastructure  development  by 
strengthening KKPPI. A new Presidential decree (No. 42/2005) adopted under 
the DPSP will strengthen the role and authority of KKPPI.24 It will help ensure a 
consistent approach to PSP across the infrastructure sectors and efficient use of 
public and private funds by sector ministries and local governments. The new 
Decree will help KKPPI to be more effective in (a) formulating strategies and 
policies to accelerate infrastructure development through the public and private 
sectors, (b) coordinating and supervising the implementation of these strategies 
and policies by the sector ministries and local governments, (c) formulating an 
implementation  policy  on  public  service  obligation  for  infrastructure,  and  (d)

PPP projects. 
 
(ii)  Strengthen  the  regulatory  framework  for  PSP  through  replacing  the  earlier 
Presidential decree (No. 7/1998) by a Presidential regulation (No. 67/2005). The

thus fulfilled its commitment made at the Indonesia Infrastructure Summit in January 2005 to

3.  Developing and Strengthening Financial System 
 
56.  Although  Indonesia’s  financial  system  has  recovered  and  been  substantially 
consolidated, the sector faces lingering fragilities in the wake of structural weaknesses and 
vulnerabilities. Under the DPSP, the Government, with technical and advisory support of ADB, 
World Bank, IMF, and other development partners, has managed to develop a strategy and 
institutional  mechanism  for  a  financial  safety  net  (FSN),  strengthened  the  prudential  and 
regulatory framework for banks, and taken steps to promote product and industry diversification, 
principally through NBFIs.  
 
57.  Development of the FSN. To provide greater financial stability and restore public sector 
confidence  in  the  banking  system,  the  Government  announced  a  three-pillar  FSN  system 
including  a  formal  deposit  insurance  scheme,  a  lender  of  last  resort  facility,  and  a  bank 
resolution  framework.  Specific  measures  include  the  enactment  of  the  Law  on  Deposit 
Insurance  in  June  2004,  which  prepared  for  the  establishment  of  the  Deposit  Insurance 
Company (LPS) in October 2005.27 Replacing the blanket guarantee, which was fully phased 
out in September 2005,28 LPS will (i) provide full insurance coverage to all eligible deposits in 
the first 6 months (until March 2006), (ii) lower this coverage to deposits up to Rp5 billion over 
the next 6 months (until September 2006), and (iii) lower the coverage to Rp1 billion after 1 year 
(until March 2007). LPS will cover only deposits up to Rp100 million from March 2007 onward. 
Concurrently, Bank Indonesia set up the Lender of Last Resort Facility to provide short-term 
liquidity support and emergency liquidity support to solvent banks in case of any systemic risks 
to the system. The Financial Stability Forum—a joint initiative being developed by MOF, Bank 
Indonesia, and LPS—will deliberate on the role, functions, and institutional arrangements for a 
bank resolution system.

Supreme Court to investigate the alleged payment of bribes of $1.6 million to judges and court

negative  perception  continues  among  investors,  given  the  general  legal  and  regulatory 
uncertainties and lack of good governance in major Government departments. This is clearly an 
area where the Government needs to pursue reforms in a vigorous manner, as recognized in 
the development policy letter (Appendix 2). Appendix 7 presents the outcomes and challenges 
in the governance and anticorruption areas.  
 
C.  Forward Looking Program 
  
68.  The development policy letter (Appendix 2) sets out the Government’s reform agenda for 
the  next  1–2  years  building  on  the  reform  momentum  of  the  DPSP.  The  forward-looking 
program includes the following commitments: 
 
1.  Macroeconomic and Creditworthiness  
 
69.  Establishment of a Fiscal Policy Office. The office will be responsible for development 
of a medium-term fiscal framework and provide policy advice to the minister of finance and the 
tax, budget, and treasury functions within MOF. The office will have a sound organizational 
structure, terms of reference for individual positions, and budget to be fully operational in 2007. 
Its functions will include analysis of proposed tax, tariff, and financial market policies; improved 
quality and usefulness of information on corporate and individual taxpayers (with due attention 
to confidentiality sufficient for effective tax forecasting and policy analysis); and improved tariff-
setting processes. 
 
70.  Assessment of Contingent Liabilities. To implement the debt management strategy 
holistically,  the  Government  will  assess  implicit  and  explicit  contingent  liabilities,  such  as 
pension liabilities and guarantees, monitor the overall debt by quantifying its costs and risks on 
public debt, and publish periodic integrated (domestic and foreign) debt reports. For regional 
government  debt,  the  Government  will  adopt  improved  procedures  for  the  loan  work-out 
procedures and a framework for issuance of debt instruments, within the broader framework of 
overall debt management.  
 
2.  Improve the Investment Climate 
 
71.  Improve Public Transparency and Enhance Financial Soundness. The Government 
will issue a new law on the regional government enterprises which, among others, will define 
their legal status, their fiscal and financial relationship with regional governments (including the

23 
treatment of continent liabilities relating to regional government enterprises in local government 
budgets), and modalities for their operational and financial restructuring. As some of these 
enterprises provide essential public services, such as water supply and sanitation, a separate 
law on their status will facilitate service provision as well as PSP.  
 
72.  Strengthen the Regulatory Framework to Attract Investments. The Government will 
issue implementing regulations to support the effective implementation of the Investment Law, 
which will, among others, involve creating a transparent negative list and shifting from a system 
of approvals to registration, requiring a reduction in business start-up time from 151 days to 30 
days by simplifying the company formation process, and revitalizing the National Team for the 
Development of Exports and Investment.  
 
73.  Introduce  Proactive  Risk  Mitigation  Measures  to  Attract  Infrastructure 
Investments. In the 2007 budget, MOF will provide for specific budgetary allocation for public 
support  to  PPP  transactions  in  infrastructure  including  both  cash  items  (i.e.,  supplemental 
subsidies), and noncash items (i.e., guarantees and other forms of contingent liabilities) if any.   
 
74.  Enhance Regional Competitiveness. The Government will draft a trade bill that will 
aim to lay out a framework for enhancing domestic and international competitiveness and 
launch efforts to monitor progress in this area.  
 
  3.  Financial Sector Reforms 
 
75.  Improve  Public  Confidence.  Through  the  Deposit  Insurance  Company,  the 
Government will continue implementing the FSN, including lowering the coverage of the deposit 
guarantee scheme to Rp1 billion by September 2006 as per the announced schedule. 
 
76.  Enhance Financial Stability. The Government and Bank Indonesia will finalize the 
institutional arrangements  for  bank  closing  and  emergency  operations  through  agreements 
between the relevant agencies, and establishment of a financial sector stability forum. 
 
77.  Promote Product and Sector Diversification. The Government will finalize and adopt 
an  NBFI  strategy  to  diversify  the  financial  sector,  and  help  meet  long-term  needs  for 
infrastructure financing.  
 
4.  Public Financial Management and Anticorruption 
78.  Streamline Budget Preparation  and Disbursements. The introduction of the new 
budget  classification  and  disbursement  system  in  2005  has  led  to  serious  delays  in 
development financing. While the procedural problems have been corrected, a major underlying 
structural weakness is in reporting of budget outturns from budget agencies to MOF in a timely 
manner. The forward-looking program will institutionalize a quarterly reporting system on budget 
spending by line agencies. The Government will also aim to improve the quality of budgeting 
process  at  entry,  by  reviewing  program  structures  and  provide  improved  guidance  to  line 
agencies in moving to a functional medium-term expenditure framework, requiring draft budget 
requirements to be submitted by the end of 2006 for preparing the 2008 budget. 
 
79.  Cash Management Account Consolidation. Building on progress under the DPSP, 
MOF will gradually expand the coverage of all Government accounts under the TSA framework, 
with the expectation of covering at least 75% of the treasury transactions 
 
80.  Transparency in Reporting. In line with the new Government accounting standards, 
the Government will improve the quality and timeliness of complete reporting on financial assets

24   
and liabilities of all line ministries, and establish a system for reconciling reports on financial 
transactions.  
 
81.  Anticorruption.  The  Government  will  focus  its  efforts  on  improving  the  public 
procurement process. The President of Indonesia has taken an active interest in procurement 
policy, emphasizing its importance in ensuring good governance and anticorruption, and has 
directed  the  National  Development  Planning  Agency  to  establish  a  high-level  procurement 
policy body that reports directly to him. In line with this, and building on progress made in public 
procurement through the adoption of the Presidential decree on procurement in 2003, the 
Government aims to set up a national procurement policy office that will consolidate the policy 
and regulatory functions in this area. In parallel, the Government will also develop an electronic 
procurement system and disseminate procurement and bidding documents. 
 
5.  Public Service Delivery 
82.  Improve  Poverty  Orientation  of  Public  Spending.  The  Government  (through 
BAPPENAS) will monitor the effectiveness and undertake independent operational assessment, 
including the fiduciary aspects, of the new compensation programs: the unconditional cash 
transfers and PKPS, with the aim of improving the impact of public expenditures on poverty 
reduction  and  achievement  of  MDGs,  and  ensuring  that  the  benefits  reach  the  intended 
beneficiaries. In parallel, the Government plans to enhance and modify unconditional cash 
transfer schemes to develop more effective conditional cash transfer systems.31

E.  Important Features 
 
84.  The DPSP has a number of distinct and innovative features. First, Indonesia with its 
strong ownership has managed to coordinate all principal development partners to develop a 
consistent and well-sequenced policy framework that prepares for macroeconomic and cross-
cutting  structural  reforms  over  the  medium  term.  The  package  subscribes  to  the  Paris 
harmonization  development  agenda.  This  has  been  achieved  by  aligning  the  development 
partners’ strategies and approaches to the Government’s development strategy for 2004–2009, 
which takes into account Indonesia’s emerging status as a middle-income country. This has

26   
involved the World Bank and ADB aligning and harmonizing their respective strategies and 
modalities. 
  
85.  Second, the macroeconomic and cross-cutting policy framework is well coordinated with 
the sector reform packages that broaden and deepen the DPSP. Examples of the sector reform 
programs  are  the  ongoing  Local  Governance  and  Finance  Program  and  the  proposed 
Infrastructure Reform and Poverty and MDG acceleration programs, currently under discussion. 
Concurrent momentum on policy dialogue on these helps ensure continuity and sustainability of 
reforms. 
 
86.  Third, the DPSP has helped establish an institutional mechanism to achieve better 
interministerial and interagency coordination to ensure proper coordination and implementation 
of reforms. An example of this is strengthening of institutional coordination between BAPPENAS 
and MOF to simplify and improve coordination of implementation of the decentralization policy 
framework, as well as approval and implementation of development projects. In addition, the 
DPSP  has  helped  define  roles,  functions,  and  responsibilities  in  approval,  financing,  and 
monitoring of infrastructure development projects. 
 
87.  Fourth, the DPSP emphasizes qualitative changes in processes and programs to ensure 
effective implementation rather than a mere focus on conditionalities that do not often yield any 
clear results on the ground. 
 
88.  These elements and approaches have many advantages. They have drawn on collective 
advice and analytical work of all the partners. They have provided the Government with the 
opportunity to steer its development program and process, keeping in perspective challenges of 
executive branch implementation and political capacity. The high ownership has already helped 
development of the future direction of reform and adjustments in areas where it was warranted. 
Together this has provided for sustainability of reforms, while reducing the transaction costs for 
all parties. 
  
F.  Financing Plan 
 
89.  The  Government  has  requested  a  loan  of  $200 million  from  ADB’s  ordinary  capital 
resources to help finance the DPSP. The loan will have a 15-year term, including a grace period 
of 3 years; an interest rate determined in accordance with ADB’s London interbank offered rate 
(LIBOR)-based lending facility; a commitment charge of 0.75% per annum; conversion options 
that may be exercised in accordance with the draft loan agreement, the loan regulations, and 
ADB’s conversion guidelines; and such other terms and conditions set forth in the draft program 
loan agreement. The Government has made its own independent decision to borrow under 
ADB’s LIBOR-based lending facility, and it has given an undertaking that this choice was not 
made on the basis of any advice from ADB. 
 
90.  The ADB funds support the reforms outlined in the development policy letter and policy 
matrix (Appendix 2). The loan size was determined by the strengths of the policy package, its 
development impact, and the importance of the sectors covered.  
 
91.  Delays in development spending in 2005, due to changes in budgetary procedures, and 
the reduction in fuel subsidies in March and October 2005, will provide fiscal space for greater 
development expenditures in 2006. However, the Government’s gross financing needs remain  
high as it must budget for (i) increases in public expenditure for poverty reduction programs, 
utilizing  the  momentum  generated  by  the  fuel  subsidy  reduction;  (ii)  larger  external  debt 
repayment ($6.5 billion in 2006 as against $4.1 billion in 2005); and (iii) increased domestic debt 
amortization from Rp20 trillion to Rp30 trillion. The Paris Club debt rescheduling reduced the

27 
Government’s net financing needs to about $2.5 billion in 2005. While the budget deficit and net 
financing needs will be lower in 2006, at 0.7% of GDP and $2.3 billion, respectively (from 0.9% 
and $2.5 billion, respectively, in 2005), amortization needs will be higher due to the end of Paris 
Club rescheduling arrangements. The financing needs will be met by raising domestic bond 
issues, sovereign bond issuance, and borrowings from multilateral development banks.  
 
G.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
1.  Program Management 
 
92.  MOF will be the Executing Agency. Implementation of the DPSP actions is coordinated 
with  a  number  of  other  ministries  and  agencies,  including  BAPPENAS,  Ministry  of  Trade, 
Ministry of Cooperatives and SMEs, and Bank Indonesia.  
 
  2.  Implementation Period 
 
93.  The DPSP period is from 1 January 2005 to 30 June 2006. All actions included in the 
Policy Matrix have been implemented during the course of 2005. The Government and ADB will 
prepare a program completion report by June 2006. The DPSP fits within the overall reform 
agenda supported under the DPLs, which covers 2003–2007.  
 
3.  Procurement and Disbursement Arrangements  
 
94.  The  program  loan  of  $200  million  will  be  released  in  a  single  tranche  upon  loan 
effectiveness.  The  loan  proceeds  will  be  used  to  finance  the  full  foreign  exchange  costs 
(excluding local duties and taxes) of items produced and procured in ADB member countries, 
excluding the items specified in the negative list of ineligible items (Appendix 9) and imports 
financed by other bilateral and multilateral sources. In accordance with the provisions of ADB’s 
Simplification of Disbursement Procedures and Related Requirements for Program Loans, the 
proceeds of the program loan will be disbursed to the Republic of Indonesia as the Borrower. 
No supporting import documentation will be required, if during each year that loan proceeds are 
expected to be disbursed the value of Indonesia’s total imports minus imports from nonmember 
countries, ineligible imports, and imports financed under other official development assistance is 
equal to or greater than the amount of the loan expected to be disbursed during such year. The 
Government  will  certify  its  compliance  with  this  formula  with  each  withdrawal  request. 
Otherwise, import documentation under existing procedures will be required. Disbursements will 
be made under the simplified procedures for program loans. In accordance with the simplified 
disbursement procedures and related requirements for program loans, all goods and services 
produced and originating in ADB member countries will be procured, with due consideration to 
economy and efficiency, in accordance with the Government’s standard public procedures and 
normal private sector commercial practices acceptable to ADB. Goods commonly traded on the 
international commodity market will be procured in accordance with procedures appropriate to 
the trade and acceptable to ADB.  
 
95.  The  reform  needs  supported  under  the  DPSP  will  be  met  through  local  currency 
counterpart funds generated from the proceeds of the DPSP loan. The provision of DPSP will 
enable  the  Government  to  reorient  its  public  expenditures  towards  high  priority  poverty 
reduction needs. 
 
96.  The Government places significant emphasis on strengthening internal control systems 
and  overall  public  financial  management,  with  support  from  the  World  Bank  through  the 
Government Financial Management and Revenue Administration Project and from ADB through 
the State Audit Reform Sector Development Program. Reforms supported under both these

28   
programs have led to initial progress in strengthening public financial management. ADB and 
World Bank have jointly undertaken the Country Financial Accountability Assessment in 2001-
02,32  which  has  been  periodically  updated.  Appendix  8  presents  the  fiduciary  assessment 
undertaken for DPSP/DPL-2, which also has an update on the Country Financial Accountability 
Assessment. 
 
4.  Anticorruption 
 
97.  ADB’s  Anticorruption  Policy  (1998)  was  explained  to  and  discussed  with  the 
Government, and all relevant ADB guidelines, including the Guidelines for Procurement under 
the  Asian  Development  Bank  Loans,  Guidelines  on  the  Use  of  Consultants  by  the  Asian 
Development Bank and its Borrowers, and the Loan Regulations, were specifically brought to 
the notice of the Government. 
 
5.  Accounting, Auditing, and Reporting 
 
98.  ADB retains the right to audit the use of loan proceeds and to verify the accuracy of the 
Government’s certification for the withdrawal applications. Prior to withdrawal, the Government 
will open a deposit account at Bank Indonesia to receive all loan proceeds. The account will be 
managed, operated, and liquidated in accordance with terms satisfactory to ADB.  
 
6.  Performance Monitoring, Evaluation and Program Review 
 
99.  MOF,  the  Coordinating  Ministry  of  Economic  Affairs,  and  BAPPENAS,  will  be 
continuously monitoring the implementation of the DPSP and its impact, in line with the overall 
program framework and outcome indicators agreed upon with the Government, and submit to 
ADB quarterly reports until the completion of the DPSP. The outcomes of the present phase of 
the DPSP/DPL-2 and the overall progress achieved will be assessed by the Government and 
the development partners by June 2006. The forward looking phase of the DPSP  will be 
formulated in 2006 subject to satisfactory progress, and based on additional analytical and 
economic and sector work being supported by ADB and other development partners. 
 
IV.  PROGRAM BENEFITS, IMPACTS, ASSUMPTIONS, AND RISKS 
A.  Expected Impacts 
 
100.  The key benefits expected from the DPSP are 
 
(i)  progress  in  meeting  the  Government’s  medium-term  objectives  of  (a) 
macroeconomic stability and creditworthiness, (b) improved investment climate, 
and (c) anticorruption and improved governance; 
(ii)  consolidation  of  recent  macroeconomic  and  policy  reforms  leading  to  the 
formulation of a credible medium-term public expenditure framework; 
(iii)  sustained engagement by ADB in policy dialogue with the Government on the 
direction  and  content  of,  and  strategies  for,  its  economic,  structural,  and 
institutional  reform  agenda;  the  DPSP  will  provide  for  policy  continuity  and 
consistency in areas where ADB has been actively involved;  
(iv)  facilitation,  through  cross-cutting  reforms,  of  sector-specific  reforms  in  areas 
where ADB is providing or planning support; and

101.  Institutional.  The  DPSP  will  contribute  to  significant  institutional  development.  The 
public expenditure reorientation program being adopted following the reduction in fuel subsidies 
will enhance national and local government capacity in public service delivery. In the financial 
sector, the Government’s support for LPS will improve public confidence in the banking system. 
The formulation of a sound FSN will help institutionalize coordination arrangements between the 
Government and Bank Indonesia in the resolution of problem banks. In the infrastructure sector, 
the DPSP will help establish KKPPI to enable it to effectively coordinate infrastructure policy 
development.  
 
102.  Social. The DPSP’s main contribution is in reducing wasteful spending, and supporting 
Government measures to effectively align its resources with its medium-term objectives of 
economic  growth  and  poverty  reduction.  The  reduction  in  fuel  subsidies,  particularly  for 
kerosene, has a negative impact on the welfare of the poor. The Government’s compensation 
program aims to mitigate this impact by providing direct cash transfers, followed by a well-
rounded  medium-term  development  program.  Appendix  10  presents  a  summary  poverty 
reduction and social impact mitigation strategy. 
 
103.  Economic.  The  nature  of  the  DPSP  does  not  allow  for  quantitative  financial  and 
economic analysis. However, significant general economic benefits will accrue to the entire 
Indonesian population from the policy initiatives under the three core areas of the DPSP. 
 
104.  Resettlement, Indigenous People, and Environment. The DPSP will cause no direct 
or indirect involuntary resettlement, nor will it lead to any issues affecting indigenous peoples. 
Based on desk review, the measures supported under the DPSP are unlikely to have any 
adverse environmental impacts. 
 
B.  Risks and Mitigating Measures 
 
105.  The DPSP is subject to the following risks: 
 
(i)  Economic volatility could worsen if the Government does not sustain the reform 
momentum  to  follow  up  on  the  recent  reduction  in  fuel  subsidies  (including 
maintaining appropriate interest rates and investment climate reforms). This risk 
is mitigated by the clear policy stance taken thus far by the Government and 
Bank Indonesia. Following the recent currency market volatility, the need for 
rapid  policy  adjustment  on  the  domestic  front  in  line  with  key  global 
developments is clearly recognized.  
(ii)  Rising interest rates may trigger financial stress in debt markets with contagion 
effects on banks and mutual funds. In turn, this may also affect growth prospects. 
The Government remains committed to closely monitoring the economic impact 
of the reforms adopted under the DPSP, with support from ADB and the other 
development partners. 
(iii)  Social tensions may increase. While the reduction in fuel subsidies announced 
on 1 October 2005 have thus far not led to any major protests, the success of the 
ongoing  unconditional  cash  transfers  program  is  vital  in  containing  public 
disenchantment. This risk is mitigated by the Government’s focus on ongoing 
evaluation of this program, with support from ADB and the World Bank. The

30   
Government  also  aims  to  formulate  a  broad-based  public  expenditure 
reorientation program, an area where ADB is actively involved. 
(iv)  The external environment is deteriorating as persistently high oil-prices result in a 
slowdown  in  world  economic  growth  and  trade,  and  create  unfavorable 
conditions  in  world  financial  markets.  The  Government’s  policy  package 
announced on 1 October provides for attracting investments in the oil and gas 
sector, which in turn will help Indonesia effectively manage its natural resources 
and reap the benefits of any windfall gains. 
(v)  Amending the tax laws is likely to be a long drawn out process and the final 
scope  of  the  laws  is  unclear,  given  the  competing  and  conflicting  interests 
between the needs for greater revenues, and the demands from the private 
sector for incentives and sound governance in tax administration. The current 
administrative  procedures  of  the  current  tax  system  have  frequently  raised 
serious  concerns  among  businesses.  Although  progress  has  been  made  in 
modernizing tax offices, the tax system needs to be strengthened, given the 
administrative  weaknesses,  perception  of  excessive  authority  given  to  tax 
officials, and the resulting excessive compliance costs. The Government remains 
committed to gradually addressing these constraints.  
(vi)  Heightened security alerts stemming from sectarian and regional conflicts and 
terrorism  could  slow  foreign  direct  investment  and  set  back  the  recovering 
tourism industry. The Government and law enforcement authorities have taken a 
range of measures aimed at rebuilding public and investor confidence.  
  
V.  ASSURANCES 
106.  In  addition  to  the  standards  assurances,  the  Government  has  given  the  following 
assurances, which are incorporated in the legal documents.  
 
(i)  Counterpart funds will be used to finance the development needs as outlined 
under the DPSP implementation arrangements. 
 
(ii)  The policies and actions taken prior to the date of the DPSP loan agreement, as 
described  in  the  development  policy  letter  (including  the  policy  matrix),  will 
continue to be in effect for the duration of the DPSP and subsequently.

lending facility; a term of 15 years, including a grace period of 3 years; and such other terms 
and conditions as are substantially in accordance with those set forth in the draft Program Loan

This note provides the IMF staff's current assessment of Indonesia's macroeconomic conditions and outlook 
for the coming period, ahead of the staff’s next Post-Program Monitoring mission to Jakarta in early 
December. 
  
Economic Conditions and Outlook 
•  Following a period of increased volatility in August and September, Indonesia’s financial markets have 
stabilized following action taken by the authorities to address the underlying imbalances in September 
and October. Monetary policy has been tightened significantly and the government announced 
sharp cuts in domestic fuel subsidies, effective October 1, to address pressures on the budget and 
the balance of payments associated with high international prices. Breaking a policy of gradual and 
modest rate increases, BI raised its one-month policy rate by 125 basis points to 10 percent in late 
August/early September and by an additional 100 basis points in early October. The last hike came 
after the sharp increases on October 1 in domestic fuel prices—88 percent on gasoline, 200 percent 
on  kerosene,  and  185  percent  on  diesel.  The  fuel  price  increase  was  accompanied  by  a 
compensation package, whereby 15½ million families will receive about US$120 annually to help 
offset the impact of rising fuel costs on their income. Markets have reacted positively to the interest 
rate and domestic fuel price increases, and both the rupiah and the stock market have strengthened 
since.  
•  The macroeconomic situation is weaker but the outlook for growth is still favorable. Real GDP 
grew by 5.1 percent in 2004 and is envisaged to increase by 5–5½ percent in 2005. This pace is 
somewhat slower than the 6 percent growth registered earlier this year, reflecting the impact of the 
recent financial market volatility on consumer and investment spending, as well as higher oil prices. 
Inflation is expected to remain in the double digits in the near-term, following the big jump in October 
to 18 percent (year-on-year) that largely reflected the impact of domestic fuel price increases but also a 
more general pickup in price pressures.  To contain underlying inflation, BI raised its policy interest 
rate by another 125 basis points on November 1, and stated its commitment to take further action, as 
needed, so as to bring inflation back down to single digits by the end of 2006.   
•  Fiscal policy remains prudent and the revised 2005 budget deficit target of about one percent of 
GDP is achievable. The revised 2005 budget approved by parliament in September entailed a slight

GOVERNANCE AND ANTICORRUPTION 
 
1.  Indonesia has made important inroads in improving governance since the 1997 Asian 
financial crisis. Corruption and public perception of corruption are discussed openly by the public 
and  the  media.  Combating  corruption  is  a  priority  under  the  Government’s  Medium-Term 
Development  Plan  (RPJM).  This  appendix  outlines  recent  progress  and  the  challenges  that 
Indonesia faces in enhancing governance and combating corruption. 
 
A.  Recent Progress 
 
2.  Political Accountability. 2004 was a landmark year in Indonesia’s political history in 
enhancing electoral accountability. The first direct presidential elections were held. The legal 
framework was amended to allow for direct elections of district heads and provincial governors; 
and  such  elections  are  under  way  for  governors,  regents,  and  mayors.  As  a  testimony  to 
democracy and electoral accountability, in the first five cases of elections of governors, only one 
of the incumbent governors was elected. While money, politics, and corruption in candidate 
selection cannot be removed in the short term, efforts and legal reforms to improve governance 
are clearly moving in the right direction.  
 
3.  Combating Corruption. In the first few months after the direct election in 2004, the 
President consistently discussed anticorruption and encouraged the relevant law enforcement 
agencies to pursue several high-profile cases. The Corruption Eradication Commission (KPK) has 
become a powerful institution. This and other new institutional measures against corruption, 
including the establishment of the Anticorruption Court, have begun to show promising results. 
The  KPK  is  currently  handling  26  cases,  with  15  at  the  initial  exploratory  stage,  6  at  the 
investigation stage, and the remaining 5 being prosecuted. These range from investigations of 
corruption  of  the  national  Government,  regional  government  institutions,  and  Parliamentary 
bodies. Some of the recent outcomes include  
 
(i)  convictions  in  the  graft  cases  against  the  governor  of  Aceh  involving  the 
procurement of a helicopter from the Russian Federation, leading to a 10-year jail 
sentence, Rp500 million in fines, and Rp6.6 billion in restitution;  
(ii)  sentencing of the acting secretary general of the General Election Commission 
(KPU) and a member of the KPU to 30-month jail terms for various malpractices in 
conducting elections; 
(iii)  launching of investigations on alleged malpractices at the top leadership levels in 
Bank Mandiri, the largest state-owned bank;  
(iv)  launching of a sting operation in the Supreme Court, revealing that court officials 
and judges may have taken bribes of $1.6 million; the KPK has been impartial and 
recently  interrogated  senior  officials,  notably  the  chief  justice  of  the  Supreme 
Court; and 
(v)  resolving and now prosecuting several cases involving senior national Government 
civil servants at the Anticorruption Court. 
 
4.  Designed on the Supreme Court reform blueprints, the Attorney General’s Office has 
engaged  civil  society  in  formulating  its  own  blueprint  for  reform.  The  office  has  set  up  an 
anticorruption team that is making progress on a number of high-profile cases, and is considering 
reopening some of the high-profile bank fraud cases dating back to the crisis. These recent 
outcomes demonstrate a clear change in the office’s willingness to deal with vested interests from

the post-crisis period, as diagnosed in comprehensive audit of the office’s practices supported by

5.  As an integral part of judicial reforms, the independent Judicial Commission was recently 
established as a key constituent of the justice system. The commission will play a balancing role 
and  offset  the  constitutional  imbalances  in  institutional  accountability  that  resulted  from  the

6.  Progress  in  fighting  corruption  is  also  being  made  by  the  local  governments,  in  the

B.  Key Challenges 
 
7.  While significant progress has been made, particularly in the last one year, much work 
remains in investigating corruption as well as curbing opportunities for systemic and institutional 
corruption. Some key challenges are outlined here. 
 
8.  Funding. While the Anticorruption Court has been fairly successful, its ad-hoc judges 
have worked for several months without being paid. Other Government internal control agencies 
generally complain about lack of resources and facilities.  Adequacy of support should be ensured 
to reinforce the Government’s commitment to anticorruption. 
 
9.  Structural Change. The Supreme Court reform process points to the need for structural 
change. The reform blueprints finalized and launched in 2003 received considerable attention and 
funding. Yet, structural changes in the Supreme Court’s operation, organization, and personnel 
systems have been slow, stalling real progress.  
 
10.  Civil Service Reforms. Indonesia has not yet undertaken any serious attempt to reform 
its civil service, particularly at the national level. As in many other policy areas, intergovernmental 
coordination remains weak in the area of civil service reforms. A large number of agencies share 
overlapping and unclear responsibilities for managing the national and regional civil services, 
including the National Civil Service Agency, State Ministry for State Apparatus Reforms, Ministry 
of  Home  Affairs,  National  Institute  of  Public  Administration,  Ministry  of  Finance,  sectoral 
ministries, and  regional  governments.  Given  the  plethora  of  institutions,  the lack  of tangible 
progress is not surprising. While some local governments have shown commitment and taken 
initiatives, these have been scuttled by the central institutions due to lack of coordination and 
concerns regarding possible financial liabilities involved in large-scale reforms. 
 
11.  KPK has proposed to the President that a modernization team should be established in 
the President’s Office to strategize and manage civil service reforms. ADB, the World Bank, and 
German Agency for Technical Cooperation have supported KPK in developing proposals for 
various civil service reform strategies and sequencing.
