FIDUCIARY ASSESSMENT 
 
A.  Background 
 
1.  The  World  Bank,  along  with  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB),  Australian  Agency  for 
International Development and International Monetary Fund (IMF), has undertaken this fiduciary 
assessment for the second Development Policy Loan (DPL-2) and the proposed Development 
Policy  Support  Program  (DPSP).  The  2001  Country  Financial  Accountability  Assessment 
highlighted a number of deficiencies in Indonesia’s public financial management system. The key 
concerns were (i) an outdated legal environment for public financial management (PFM); (ii) an 
opaque and inefficient budget formulation process, including the separation of recurrent and 
development budgets; (iii) an inefficient payments system and weak monitoring arrangements; (iv) 
fragmented cash management and government banking arrangements; (v) unreliable accounting 
and reporting systems; (vi) inadequate auditing of government sectors; and (vii) overlaps between 
external and internal audit agencies, reflecting unclear roles and responsibilities. 
 
2.  To address these constraints, in 2002 the Government embarked on a PFM modernization 
program, initiating the drafting of the state finance, treasury, and audit laws. Following their 
adoption in 2003–2004, it initiated the implementation of the World Bank-supported Government 
Financial Management and Revenue Administration Project (GFMRAP) in June 2004 and the 
ADB-supported State Audit Reform Sector Development Program (STAR) in December 2004. 
These two initiatives together provide a road map for PFM, building on earlier Government work.  
 
B.  Public Financial Management Reforms 
 
3.  Key PFM reforms include the following:  
 
(i)  The Law on State Finances (2003) provides for the basic fiscal framework, based 
on international classification standards for developing the budget, a clear budget 
timetable, and reporting requirements to Parliament. Under the law, development 
and recurrent budgets will be unified, and a medium-term expenditure framework 
system and performance-based budgeting introduced. 
(ii)  The National Development Planning System Law (2004) provides the legal basis 
for  the  national  development  planning  process,  and  for  linking  planning  with 
budgeting. 
(iii)  The  State  Treasury  Law  (2004)  outlines  the  basis  for  modernizing  budget 
execution  and  reporting.  Treasury  reforms  being  undertaken  include  steps  to 
rationalize the current proliferation of Government bank accounts; to centralize 
cash  management,  and  simplify  and  speed  up  the  payments  system;  and  to 
improve  reporting  on budget  execution.  Government  financial  reporting  will be 
improved through the implementation of Government accounting standards on a 
modified accrual basis, but with an eventual move to full accrual accounting.  
(iv)  The State Audit Law (2004) lays out the broad legal framework for operation of the 
country’s supreme audit institution, BPK, to reinforce its position and mandate as 
the independent external audit institution reporting to Parliament.  
(v)  The  Presidential  decree  on  Procurement  (No.80/2003)  introduces  many 
improvements in the procurement regime and lays out a timetable for establishing 
a national policy formulation and oversight agency. An omnibus procurement law is 
envisaged for consolidating, clarifying, and simplifying the numerous procurement 
rules and regulations.

5.  To  effectively  implement  the  new  legal  and  regulatory  framework,  the  Government 
restructured  the  Ministry  of  Finance  (MOF)  in  2004,  leading  to  the  establishment  of  a  new 
directorate general (DG) for budget and fiscal balance and a new DG for treasury, broadly in line 
with previous IMF recommendations. All directors general and directors have been appointed. 
Both the budget and treasury functions have been strengthened; the director general, treasury, 
oversees all treasury functions including cash and debt management, fixed asset management, 
and government fiscal reporting. A description of the key steps taken follows. 
 
  a.  Budget Reforms 
 
6.  Development of annual budgets through adoption of (i) the new economic and fiscal 
framework (including a medium-term expenditure framework to be prepared on a 3-year rolling 
basis), (ii) clearer expenditure classification, including the integration of routine and development 
budgets; and (iii) enhanced ex post fiscal reporting through the provision of comprehensive 
financial statements, including a balance sheet, cash-flow statement, and the budget execution 
report to Parliament within 6 months of the end of the fiscal year. 
 
7.  Planning and budgeting functions are integrated by formally linking ministerial work plans 
with budgets, and clarifying the respective roles of planning and budgeting functions. 
 
8.  The following changes are incorporated in the 2005 budget: 
 
(i)  A new functional and program classification, consistent with the IMF Government 
Financial Statistics Manual (GFSM) 2001, is used for cash-based transactions. 
This requires review to ensure it adequately allows program management and 
performance budgeting approaches at the agency level.  
(ii)  Forward estimates were introduced for the first time, although much more work 
needs to be done to fully adopt the medium-term expenditure framework approach. 
International  advisers  wrote  an  extensive  number  of  papers  and  provided 
presentations  to  explain  the  concept.  The  work  plan  regulations  provide  for 
indicative budget ceilings to be issued for 2 years, but in the 2005 and 2006 
budgets indicative ceilings are issued only for the forthcoming budget year.  
(iii)  Recurrent and development budgets are unified, with components from the former 
development budget classified into economic categories. 
(iv)  Limited progress has been made in developing a performance-oriented budget. 
Although a start has been made with the fiscal 2005 budget, full implementation 
will take more time as understanding seems to be limited, and no clear strategy 
has yet been developed to operationalize performance orientation.  
 
b.  Treasury Reforms 
 
9.  Budget Execution and Public Resource Management. The new legal framework will 
allow  the  Government  to  manage  its  financial  assets,  debt,  and  cash  more  efficiently  and 
effectively.  The  MOF  reorganization  will  strengthen  accountability,  eliminate  overlap  and 
duplication of functions, and enable MOF to focus more effectively on its core functions. The

10.  Rationalization of the Treasury System. The new Directorate General (DG) of Treasury 
was established under the MOF reorganization. Regional accounting offices and local verification 
offices  have  been  merged  with  regional  administrative  offices  under  the  DG  treasury,  with

11.  The  planned  introduction  of  a  treasury  single  account  (TSA)  and  automation  of  the 
treasury payment system are key reforms. Progress in this area has been slow, although a 
detailed work plan has now been developed, especially for establishing the TSA, which involves 
the  progressive  rationalization  of  a  vast  number  of  separate  government  bank  accounts. 
Substantial idle cash balances continue.  
 
12.  In the area of fiscal reporting, the State Treasury Law requirement for the complete 
introduction of accrual accounting by 2008 is very ambitious. The transition to the accruals-based 
GFSM 2001 needs to be gradual, recognizing its dependence on an operational TSA, a double-
entry ledger system allowing for the regular reconciliation of accounting and bank information, and 
the  new  state  treasury  and  budget  system.  The  latest  annual  Government-wide  financial 
statements for 2003, which include a balance sheet as well as a budget execution statement, are 
of doubtful quality, reflecting inadequate information on financial assets (including cash) and 
liabilities,  lack  of  other  accruals-based  information,  failure  to  fully  reconcile  banking  and 
accounting information from line ministries, and shortcomings in accounting skills in the line 
ministries.   
 
13.  Development and Adoption of Government Accounting Standards. The Accounting 
Standards Committee, which has been in operation for a few years, has put in place a due 
process for the development of Government accounting standards that are well aligned with 
comparable international standards. An initial set of 11 government accounting standards have 
been formally adopted through a Presidential decree (No. 25/2005). These standards are based 
on a modified accrual approach and cover a budget implementation report, overall cash-flow 
statement, and supplementary information on various assets and liabilities to be elaborated in a 
balance  sheet.  Each  ministry  and  agency  is  required  to  prepare  a  financial  accountability 
statement, based on these standards. Implementing these new standards across government will 
require extensive training and some reengineering of related business processes in line ministries 
and agencies. This task will impose challenges, given the inherently weak capacities in ministries.

scope of audits. It can audit all government entities and operations as it deems appropriate. In 
addition, public disclosure of all BPK audit reports is now mandatory. Overlap and duplication on 
audit mandates between BPK and the State Audit and Inspection Agency (BPKP) and inspectors

The National Poverty Reduction Strategy (NPRS) has five basic strategies for poverty reduction: (i) broadening 
opportunities, (ii) empowering community institutions, (iii) increasing capacity, (iv) providing social protection, and (v) 
promoting global partnerships. The NPRS is to be implemented through macroeconomic strategy and policies for 
fulfilling basic rights, for promoting gender justice and equality, and regional development. The NPRS considers 
macroeconomic policies as the foundation for reducing poverty through a supportive business environment and broad 
opportunities for increasing the capability of the poor through four related objectives to (i) create macroeconomic 
stability, (ii) promote economic growth, (iii) increase opportunities for employment and entrepreneurship, and (iv) 
reduce inequalities between regions. The NPRS considers the willingness of central and local governments to manage 
the budget in an open, accountable, efficient, and effective way— an essential prerequisite for implementing the 
NPRS. It recognizes that partnerships are necessary for implementing the NPRS with the private sector and financial 
and nonfinancial banking Institutions identified as key stakeholders.  
 
The country poverty assessment1 and country poverty partnership agreement2 consider macroeconomic stability as a 
fundamental underpinning to poverty reduction. Under the agreement, ADB has agreed to support the Government to

improvement of key basic services such as health, education, water supply, and sanitation through public-private 
partnerships and the need to expand a system of social protection. At the same time, the poverty partnership 
agreement notes the tremendous fiscal constraint facing the Government in the medium term and therefore the need 
to make the best use of existing resources.
